Health functions
	The Agency has the following functions in relation to health—
		the protection of the community (or any part of the community) againstinfectious disease and other dangers to health;
		the prevention of the spread of infectious disease;
		the provision of assistance to any other person who exercises functions inrelation to the matters mentioned in paragraphs (a) and (b).
	The Agency also has such other functions in relation to health as—
		the Secretary of State (after consultation with the National Assembly forWales) directs;
		the National Assembly (after consultation with the Secretary of State)directs.
	The Secretary of State may (after consultation with the National Assembly)direct the Agency to exercise any function conferred on him by or under anenactment.
	The National Assembly may (after consultation with the Secretary of State)direct the Agency to exercise any function conferred on it by or under anenactment.
	The giving of a direction under subsection (3) or (4) does not—
		transfer the function to the Agency;
		prevent the exercise of the function by the Secretary of State or theNational Assembly (as the case may be).
	Subsection (1) does not apply to a function to the extent that it—
		is exercisable within devolved competence (within the meaning of theScotland Act [1998 (c. 46)](/id/ukpga/1998/46?view=plain "Go to item oflegislation"));
		relates to a transferred matter (within the meaning of section 4(1) of theNorthern Ireland Act [1998 (c. 47)](/id/ukpga/1998/47?view=plain "Go to itemof legislation")).
	The Scottish Ministers may by order confer on the Agency a function of anydescription falling within subsection (1) to the extent that it is exercisablewithin devolved competence.
	An order under subsection (7) must not be made—
		for the purpose of conferring a function unless the Scottish Ministers haveobtained the agreement of the Secretary of State;
		for the purpose of removing a function unless the Scottish Ministers haveconsulted the Secretary of State.
	An order under subsection (7) must be made by statutory instrument subjectto annulment by a resolution of the Scottish Parliament.
	The Department of Health, Social Services and Public Safety in NorthernIreland may by order confer on the Agency a function of any descriptionfalling within subsection (1) to the extent that it is exercisable for thepurposes of a transferred matter.
	An order under subsection (10) must not be made—
		for the purpose of conferring a function unless the Department has obtainedthe agreement of the Secretary of State;
		for the purpose of removing a function unless the Department has consultedthe Secretary of State.
	An order under subsection (10) must be made by statutory rule for thepurposes of the Statutory Rules (Northern Ireland) Order 1979 ([S.I. 1979/1573(N.I. 12)](/id/nisi/1979/1573?view=plain "Go to item of legislation")) subjectto negative resolution (within the meaning of section 41(6) of theInterpretation Act (Northern Ireland) [1954 (c. 33(N.I.))](/id/apni/1954/33?view=plain "Go to item of legislation").

Radiation protection functions
	The Agency has the following functions in relation to risks connected withradiation (whether ionising or not)—
		the advancement of the acquisition of knowledge about protection from suchrisks;
		the provision of information and advice in relation to the protection ofthe community (or any part of the community) from such risks.
	The Agency must also exercise such of the functions which are exercisableat the date of commencement of this section by the National RadiologicalProtection Board as are specified in a direction given by the appropriateauthority.
	The appropriate authority may direct the Agency to exercise any otherfunction in relation to protection from the risks mentioned in subsection (1).
	If a Health and Safety body asks the Agency to enter into an agreement withthe body for the Agency to carry out any of the body’s functions relating toradiation (whether ionising or not) on the body’s behalf, the appropriateauthority may direct the Agency to do so.
	In the exercise of any function it has under this section which relates toany matter in respect of which a Health and Safety body has a function theAgency must—
		consult the body;
		have regard to the body’s policies.
	A direction under this section must not be given unless the person givingthe direction has consulted each of the other persons mentioned in section 6.
	Each of the following is a Health and Safety body—
		the Health and Safety Commission in relation to Great Britain;
		the Health and Safety Executive for Northern Ireland.
	The giving of a direction under subsection (2) or (3) does not—
		transfer the function to the Agency;
		prevent the exercise of the function by the appropriate authority.

Co-operation 
	In the exercise of its functions the Agency must co-operate with otherbodies which exercise functions relating to health or any other matter inrelation to which the Agency also exercises functions.
	A body other than the Agency mentioned in subsection (1) must co-operatewith the Agency in the exercise by the body of any such function it has.
	In subsection (1) the reference to other bodies includes bodies establishedoutside the United Kingdom.

Appropriate authority
	Except as otherwise provided for in this section the appropriate authorityis the Secretary of State.
	In relation to any function which is exercisable in relation to Wales bythe National Assembly for Wales acting alone, the appropriate authority is theNational Assembly.
	In relation to any function which is exercisable for the purposes of atransferred matter (within the meaning of section 4(1) of the Northern IrelandAct [1998 (c. 47)](/id/ukpga/1998/47?view=plain "Go to item of legislation")),the appropriate authority is the Department of Health, Social Services andPublic Safety in Northern Ireland.
	In relation to any function which is exercisable within devolved competence(within the meaning of the Scotland Act [1998 (c.46)](/id/ukpga/1998/46?view=plain "Go to item of legislation")), theappropriate authority is the Scottish Ministers.
	In relation to any function which is exercisable in relation to any part ofthe United Kingdom by more than one of the persons mentioned in subsections(1) to (4), the appropriate authority is both or all (as the case may be) ofthose persons acting jointly.

Transfer of property and staff, etc.
	The Secretary of State may make a scheme for the transfer of property,rights and liabilities of the bodies mentioned in subsection (2) to theAgency.
	These are the bodies—
		the Special Health Authority known as the Health Protection Agencyestablished by the Health Protection Agency (Yr Asiantaeth Diogelu Iechyd)(Establishment) Order 2003 ([S.I. 2003/505](/id/uksi/2003/505?view=plain "Goto item of legislation"));
		the National Radiological Protection Board.
	The Secretary of State must not make a scheme in respect of the bodymentioned in subsection (2)(a) unless he first consults the National Assemblyfor Wales.
	The Secretary of State must not make a scheme in respect of the bodymentioned in subsection (2)(b) unless he first consults—
		the Scottish Ministers;
		the Department of Health, Social Services and Public Safety in NorthernIreland;
		the National Assembly for Wales.
	The appropriate authority may make a scheme for the transfer of property,rights and liabilities of a relevant body to the Agency.
	A relevant body is a body—
		established otherwise than by or under any enactment,
		all of the functions of which are conferred on the Agency in pursuance of adirection or order under this Act, and
		which is specified in a scheme.
	If the appropriate authority varies or revokes a direction or order undersection 2 or 3, it may make a scheme for the transfer of the rights andliabilities of the Agency specified in subsection (8) to a relevanttransferee.
	The rights and liabilities are the rights and liabilities relating to thecontract of employment of any individual whose employment, in the opinion ofthe appropriate authority, relates wholly or principally to the Agency’sexercise of a removed function.
	A removed function is a function which is the subject of the direction ororder which the appropriate authority varies or revokes.
	A relevant transferee is an entity which, following the variation orrevocation of the direction or order, is to exercise the removed function.
	The appropriate authority must not make a scheme under subsection (7)unless it first consults, in respect of the scheme, each person or body thatit must consult in respect of the variation or revocation of the direction ororder under section 2 or 3.
	Schedule 2 makes provision in relation to a scheme under this section.
	Enactment includes—
		any provision of or instrument made under an Act of the ScottishParliament;
		Northern Ireland legislation.

Directions 
	A direction—
		must be given in writing;
		may be varied by a subsequent such direction.
	A direction under section 2(2), (3) or (4) must be given in regulationsmade by statutory instrument.
	A statutory instrument making regulations giving a direction under section2(2)(a) or (3) is subject to annulment in pursuance of a resolution of eitherHouse of Parliament.

Health care provision: standards
	In so far as any health care is provided by or for the Agency it is to betreated for the purposes of the standards provisions as an English NHS body.
	Health care must be construed in accordance with section 45 of the Healthand Social Care (Community Health and Standards) Act [2003 (c.43)](/id/ukpga/2003/43?view=plain "Go to item of legislation").
	The standards provisions are Chapters 2, 3 and 10 of Part 2 of that Act.
	The references in section 53 of that Act (failings of bodies) to specialmeasures are, in relation to the Agency, references to anything that may bedone by the appropriate authority in pursuance of section 4 above.
	Section 57 of that Act (studies as to economy and efficiency, etc.) doesnot apply to the Agency.
	This section does not extend to Scotland and Northern Ireland.

Amendments and repeals
	Schedule 3 contains amendments.
	Schedule 4 contains repeals.
	A reference in Schedule 1 to the National Assembly for Wales (Transfer ofFunctions) Order 1999 ([S.I. 1999/672](/id/uksi/1999/672?view=plain "Go toitem of legislation")) to an enactment amended by Schedule 3 below must betaken to be a reference to the enactment as so amended.
